titleproper.value: Guide to the Jacob Freeman Papers <num>ALBA.227</num>

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

addressline: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace
        <date>2017-08-11T15:17:39</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

abstract.value:
Jacob Freeman (1918-1938) went to Spain
        in 1937 to fight with the International Brigades in the Spanish Civil War. The ship taking
        him there was torpedoed, but Freeman remained unharmed. He went on to become an observer,
        map-maker and scout in the Abraham Lincoln Brigade. Freeman was wounded in the head by
        shrapnel in August 1938, and was killed in action in September 1938. The bulk of this
        collection consists of letters Freeman wrote from Spain to family members; as well as
        correspondence documenting the attempts of Freeman's father, Samuel, to obtain information
        about his missing son.

p.value:
Materials are open to researchers. Please contact the Tamiment Library & Robert F.
        Wagner Labor Archives for more information and to schedule an appointment,
        tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu or 212-998-2630.

Published citations should take the following form: <lb/><lb/>Identification of item, date;
        Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number; <lb/>Tamiment Library/Robert
        F. Wagner Labor Archives <lb/>Elmer Holmes Bobst Library <lb/>70 Washington Square South
        <lb/>New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.

Samuel Freeman, who had supported his son's commitment to the Republican cause, worked in
        New York to raise money for the Friends of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade (FALB) while Jacob
        was in Spain. After Jacob's letters abruptly stopped, Samuel tried assiduously for several
        months to obtain information about his son.

<emph render="bold">Series II: Subject Files, 1935-1939</emph>. This series includes two
        newspaper clippings about student activities from before Jacob Freeman went to Spain, and an
        article about Samuel having seen a photo of Jacob in Barcelona, wounded (a later letter from
        Jacob assures Samuel that he was mistaken in thinking the photograph was of his son). Other
        materials include an ophthalmology exam report and a handwritten note made by Jacob Freeman
        about a comrade owing him money, both from his time in Spain; International Brigades
        postcards annotated by Jacob Freeman; an issue of the Volunteer for Liberty, the
        International Brigades newspaper, with an article by Freeman on the responsibilities of an
        observer and scout in the military; and a Jack Freeman Memorial Roll Call membership issued
        by City College.

corpname.value: Friends of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade
